title: Is the force (F) in Coulomb's Law describing the average electrical force between two charges? Since doesn't the force change at different locations in an electric field? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is the force (F) in Coulomb’s Law describing the average electrical force between two charges? No its the exact figure. We’ll start with two charges, one positive and one negative, separated by a distance D.  Suppose that, when we plug in the values, Coulomb’s Law gives us an answer of 10 newtons. That means the positive charge will be pulled towards the negative charge by a force with a strength of 10 newtons, and the negative charge will also feel a force of 10 newtons (towards the positive charge). Since doesn’t the force change at different locations in the electric field? Let’s find out. We’ll keep our negative charge in the same place and move our positive charge.  Now according to Coulumb’s Law the force only depends on the magnitude of the two charges and the distance between them. None of those have changed so it predicts the force should be 10 newtons. Sure enough if we do the experiment that’s what we find. In fact if we move the positive charge to any location we’ll still get 10 newtons of force as long as we don’t change the distance between the charges. The same happens if we move the negative charge. Of course the direction of the force will change, but the original question is talking about the scalar form of Coulumb’s Law, which doesn’t tell us the direction anyway. So in general if we move a charge around in an electric field we will change the force felt by that charge. But Coulomb’s Law isn’t doesn’t apply to just any electric field, it only applies to the electric field around a single point charge. The electric field around a point charge is symmetrical, so the direction between the charge we’re using to measure the field and the charge that creates the field doesn’t affect the magnitude of the force felt at that point. All that matters is the distance, which Coulomb’s Law already takes into account.

No, it describes the force between two charges at a fixed separation. F=kQq/r^2 It is like going to the cash machine and getting a balance for your account. It is not an average, it is an sppecific valkue. If things change like moving money in or out, the balance changes. If the charges move and the separation changes, the Force they exert on each other changes.
